channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2018 The New York Times Company

item.title: Vatican Power Struggle Bursts Into Open as Conservatives Pounce
item.media:description: Archbishop Carlo Maria Viganò, center, the former top Vatican diplomat in the United States, in Portland, Me., in 2014.
item.description: Vatican intrigues usually remain behind the walls. The battle now is fueled by a potent combination of conservative anger and the child sex abuse scandals.
item.dc:creator: JASON HOROWITZ

item.title: Russia Hated John McCain, and Will Miss Him Dearly
item.media:description: Senators John McCain, left, and Tom Cotton at a Senate hearing last year on Russian interference in the 2016 election.
item.description: The death of the Arizona senator has deprived Moscow of its favorite punching bag, the supposed leader of a global conspiracy of “Russophobes.”
item.dc:creator: ANDREW HIGGINS

item.title: War Crimes Report Accuses Saudi Arabia and U.A.E. in Yemen
item.media:description: The old quarter of Sana, Yemen, in August. The house in the foreground was destroyed by an airstrike.
item.description: A U.N. panel found evidence of torture, rape and mass civilian casualties, placing blame on both Houthi rebels and the Saudi-led coalition.
item.dc:creator: NICK CUMMING-BRUCE
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: Iran’s Parliament Gives President a Rare Rebuke
item.media:description: President Hassan Rouhani of Iran, second from left, arriving in Parliament in Tehran on Tuesday to answer lawmakers’ questions. He blamed United States sanctions for Iran’s troubles.
item.description: Lawmakers asked Hassan Rouhani to explain an economic crisis that has worsened as a result of U.S. sanctions, and then voted to reject his explanations.
item.dc:creator: RICHARD PÉREZ-PEÑA

item.title: German Far-Right and Counterprotesters Clash in Chemnitz
item.media:description: Far-right demonstrators faced police officers in Chemnitz, Germany, on Monday night. They had gathered for a second day as an Iraqi and a Syrian were arrested on suspicion of involvement in a fatal stabbing over the weekend.
item.description: Demonstrations in the city began after a 35-year-old man was killed over the weekend, and nationalists called on people to “defend” their country from immigrants.
item.dc:creator: MELISSA EDDY
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: 17 Migrants Found in Australia After Boat Runs Aground in Crocodile-Infested Waters
item.media:description: A boat carrying 17 migrants ran aground in Queensland, Australia, on Sunday. Those aboard waded through dangerous waters before being picked up by fishermen and the authorities.
item.description: The authorities said the group had violated the law, but it was unclear whether they would be deported home or sent to offshore detention facilities.
item.dc:creator: ISABELLA KWAI

item.title: 300,000 Troops and 900 Tanks: Russia’s Biggest Military Drills Since Cold War
item.media:description: A Russian soldier patrolling near military vehicles in Moscow in April.
item.description: Soviet-era military exercises once aimed at preparing for war with China are being reshaped. Now, Beijing is taking part.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW HIGGINS

item.title: Duterte Is Accused of Murder in New Filing at Hague Court
item.media:description: Relatives of Filipinos killed in the Philippine drug war, along with activists, at a protest Tuesday in the Manila area.
item.description: Relatives of eight Filipinos killed in President Rodrigo Duterte’s drug war filed the new complaint against him at the International Criminal Court.
item.dc:creator: FELIPE VILLAMOR
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: The Man Who Took On the Pope: The Story Behind the Viganò Letter
item.media:description: Archbishop Carlo Maria Viganò, in Chicago in 2014, has shaken the Roman Catholic Church to its core.
item.description: Archbishop Carlo Maria Viganò wrote a 7,000-word letter that called for the resignation of Pope Francis, accusing him of covering up sexual abuse in the Roman Catholic Church.
item.dc:creator: JASON HOROWITZ

item.title: Anguish at U.N., but No Action Plan, for Rohingya Atrocities
item.media:description: The actress Cate Blanchett, a good-will ambassador for the United Nations’ refugee agency, spoke to the Security Council on Tuesday and offered a grim assessment of efforts to help Rohingya refugees who were driven from Myanmar.
item.description: Western powers called for accountability after a United Nations panel found that Myanmar’s generals should be punished. But no steps were offered for how to do that.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL SCHWIRTZ
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: Nafta, Google, Trump: Your Tuesday Evening Briefing
item.media:credit: Darryl Dyck/The Canadian Press, via Associated Press
item.description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
item.dc:creator: JOUMANA KHATIB and VIRGINIA LOZANO

item.title: Nafta Is Suddenly in Doubt, and Canada Reels
item.media:description: A worker at the Chrysler assembly plant in Brampton, Ontario. President Trump has threatened to impose hefty tariffs on Canadian-made cars and auto parts.
item.description: Most economists say an end to the trade deal would not severely harm the economy in and of itself, but they fear international investment could be chilled.
item.dc:creator: CATHERINE PORTER

item.title: Was a Scientist’s Death Murder or an ‘Act of Mercy’?
item.media:description: Mary E. White, an environmental scientist, who died in Bundanoon, Australia, in early August. Her daughter, Barbara Eckersley, has been charged with her murder in a case that has stirred debate about euthanasia.
item.description: Mary E. White was a highly regarded scientist whose mind was ravaged by dementia. After her daughter was accused of murdering her this month, it set off a broader debate in Australia on euthanasia.
item.dc:creator: RICK ROJAS

item.title: France’s Environment Minister Resigns Live on Radio, a Blow to Macron
item.media:description: Nicolas Hulot, who quit his post as environment minister, said Tuesday that in France, the environment “isn’t being handled like a priority issue.”
item.description: Nicolas Hulot, one of President Emmanuel Macron’s most popular ministers, said the government was not doing enough to tackle pressing environmental issues.
item.dc:creator: AURELIEN BREEDEN
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change

item.title: Inside a Neonatal Clinic in South Sudan: ‘In Some Ways, It Felt Wrong to Be Here’
item.media:description: Megan Specia interviews Dr. Rose Tongan on a break during her shift at the Juba Teaching Hospital's neonatal clinic.
item.description: Minutes after two journalists started following a doctor on her rounds of a newborn ward, a baby stopped breathing.
item.dc:creator: MEGAN SPECIA and KASSIE BRACKEN

item.title: Pentagon May Restart Major War Games Amid Rising Tensions With North Korea
item.media:description: “We have no plans at this time to suspend any more exercises,” Defense Secretary Jim Mattis said at a Pentagon news conference on Tuesday.
item.description: The statement by Defense Secretary Jim Mattis was yet another sign that the diplomatic thaw between Washington and Pyongyang is coming to an end.
item.dc:creator: HELENE COOPER, THOMAS GIBBONS-NEFF and EDWARD WONG
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament

item.title: South Sudan Rebels Refuse to Sign Peace Deal
item.description: Some rebel leaders said disputes over power sharing and a new constitution were not sufficiently addressed in the latest version of the agreement.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: Pope Francis on Gay Children: ‘Don’t Condemn, Have a Dialogue’
item.description: Pope Francis, taking questions after his papal visit to Ireland, urged parents not to ignore their gay children or throw them out of the family.

item.title: Nafta, John McCain, Pope Francis: Your Monday Evening Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
item.dc:creator: KAREN ZRAICK and HIROKO MASUIKE

item.title: North Korean State Media Denounce U.S. as Diplomacy Stalls
item.media:description: North Korean soldiers in the Demilitarized Zone last week. Over the weekend, North Korean state media warned that the diplomacy forged between the North’s leader and President Trump was in jeopardy.
item.description: Belligerent articles alleged “extremely provocative and dangerous” American military moves after the United States canceled a trip by Secretary of State Mike Pompeo.
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament

item.title: Pope Francis, the Accusations and the Back Story
item.media:description: Pope Francis celebrating Mass at Phoenix Park, in Dublin on Sunday.
item.description: Here are questions and answers about allegations that Francis helped cover up a cardinal’s misconduct and about the deeper church disputes behind them.
item.dc:creator: RICHARD PÉREZ-PEÑA

item.title: Aleksei Navalny, Kremlin Critic, Is Jailed Ahead of Russian Pension Protests
item.media:description: Aleksei A. Navalny, a leading Russian opposition figure, has accused the authorities of detaining him to disrupt the planning of nationwide protests.
item.description: The latest short jail term for the opposition leader comes before expected demonstrations against an unpopular plan to raise the retirement age in Russia.
item.dc:creator: LINCOLN PIGMAN

item.title: 17,500 Dutchmen Gave Their DNA in a Murder Inquiry. After 20 Years, an Arrest.
item.media:description: Ingrid Schafer Poels, the chief of police in Maastricht, the Netherlands, addressing the news media on Monday about the murder case.
item.description: A practice known as familial DNA profiling, in which investigators take samples from potential relatives of a suspect, has led to the resolution of two major Dutch cold murder cases.
item.dc:creator: MILAN SCHREUER

item.title: Hong Kong Professor Faces Murder Trial in ‘Yoga Ball Killing’
item.media:description: Khaw Kim-sun, accused of murdering his wife and daughter in 2015, being escorted by the police in Hong Kong last year.
item.media:credit: Apple Daily, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: Dr. Khaw Kim-sun, an anesthesiologist, is accused of using an exercise ball filled with carbon monoxide to kill his wife and daughter.
item.dc:creator: TIFFANY MAY

item.title: Pope on Cover-up Allegations: ‘I Will Not Say One Word on This’
item.description: Pope Francis responded to questions about a claim by a former Vatican ambassador that he helped cover up abuse allegations against Cardinal Theodore McCarrick in 2013.

item.title: U.S. Commander Urges More Transparency in Yemen Strike on School Bus
item.media:description: Yemeni children take part in a mass funeral for children killed in an air strike by the Saudi-led coalition in Saada, Yemen, this month.
item.description: The top United States air commander in the Middle East frustrated with the Saudi-led air campaign in Yemen after an airstrike killed more than 40 children.
item.dc:creator: ERIC SCHMITT
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Airstrike Near Tajikistan Border Kills Taliban, Afghans Say
item.description: Officials said Tajikistan’s Air Force carried out the strike, but the accounts seemed to conflict with what is known about its capabilities.
item.dc:creator: NAJIM RAHIM and ROD NORDLAND

item.title: Ally of South Korean Leader Conspired to Rig Online Opinion, Inquiry Finds
item.media:description: Kim Kyoung-soo, a close aide of President Moon Jae-in of South Korea, is accused of illegally trying to influence public opinion ahead of Mr. Moon’s election last year.
item.description: A special counsel found that a key ally of President Moon of South Korea conspired in an illegal attempt to influence public opinion ahead of Mr. Moon’s election.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Volkswagen’s Effort to Stop Scandals Needs More Work, Report Says
item.media:description: Volkswagen cars for export in the port of Emden, Germany, in March. “It is not easy to come from shock to shame to change,” a senior executive said on Monday.
item.description: The automaker, which was humbled after falsifying emissions data, still has work to do to protect potential whistle-blowers, according to its U.S. monitor.
item.dc:creator: JACK EWING

item.title: Personal Journeys: From Ride Share to Rickshaw: Wedding-Shopping Adventures in India
item.media:description: Bridal outfits at Indu Fashions in the Chandni Chowk district of Old Delhi, India.
item.media:credit: Poras Chaudhary for The New York Times
item.description: Champagne and cake? Try chai and samosas: A bride-to-be returns to India to shop for her wedding in a bumpy, smog-filled trip, in-laws in tow.
item.dc:creator: SHEILA MARIKAR

item.title: Myanmar Generals Should Face Genocide Charges Over Rohingya, U.N. Says
item.media:description: A United Nations panel found that evidence against Senior Gen. Min Aung Hlaing and five other generals in Myanmar made it a priority to try them in an international court in relation to “the gravest crimes” against Rohingya Muslims and other minorities.
item.media:credit: Ye Aung Thu/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: A United Nations panel says that Myanmar’s top general, Min Aung Hlaing, should be among those tried for a “plan for destruction” of Rohingya Muslims.
item.dc:creator: NICK CUMMING-BRUCE
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Scott Morrison Is a New Kind of Australian Prime Minister: An Evangelical Christian
item.media:description: Prime Minister Scott Morrison of Australia with his wife, Jenny, and daughters after being sworn in on Friday. Mr. Morrison speaks openly about his evangelical faith.
item.description: Sworn in last week, the new leader has talked openly and often about his evangelical Christian faith — a rarity in Australian politics.
item.dc:creator: RICK ROJAS

item.title: In Russia, a Top University Lacks Just One Thing: Students
item.media:description: The European University in St. Petersburg has been under attack by some Russian officials.
item.media:credit: Maxim Babenko for The New York Times
item.description: The European University at St. Petersburg lost its teaching license after attacks from conservative nationalists who resent its Western orientation.
item.dc:creator: IVAN NECHEPURENKO

item.title: North Korea to Expel Japanese Tourist Accused of Crime
item.media:description: Women crossing a train track in Nampo, North Korea. A Japanese tourist was detained after apparently filming footage of a military facility in the area.
item.description: North Korea says it has decided to “leniently condone” the man and expel him “on the principle of humanitarianism.”
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: In Brazil, ‘Queer Museum’ Is Censored, Debated, Then Celebrated
item.media:description: Lining up in Rio de Janeiro to see the “Queer Museum” exhibition.
item.media:credit: Dado Galdieri for The New York Times
item.description: A controversial exhibition was shut down after protests by religious groups, inciting a national argument about art. After a record-setting fund-raising drive, the show reopened to large crowds.
item.dc:creator: ERNESTO LONDOÑO
item.category: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships

item.title: The Nuclear Power Plant of the Future May Be Floating Near Russia
item.media:description: The port of Murmansk, in far northwest Russia, is the site of a technologically advanced but potentially risky experiment: a floating nuclear power plant.
item.media:credit: Maxim Babenko for The New York Times
item.description: Offshore reactors could be cheaper, safer and more flexible, proponents say, making them a useful weapon against climate change. Critics are incredulous.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW E. KRAMER

item.title: Pope Francis Asks Forgiveness for Abuses in Ireland
item.description: During a ceremony in Dublin on Sunday, the pope asked forgiveness for sexual abuses committed by members of the Roman Catholic clergy in the country.

item.title: Iran’s Parliament Removes Finance Minister From Office
item.media:description: Masoud Karbasian in Tehran on Sunday before lawmakers voted to remove him as finance minister.
item.description: Critics of the ousted official, Masoud Karbasian, said the government had failed to shore up the economy after President Trump reinstated sanctions.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: Pope Francis Long Knew of Cardinal’s Abuse and Must Resign, Archbishop Says
item.media:description: In a letter published on Sunday, Archbishop Carlo Maria Viganò claimed that Pope Francis was aware of abuse allegations against an American prelate.
item.description: Carlo Maria Viganò, once the Vatican’s top diplomat in the U.S., claims Francis was complicit in covering up sexual abuse by Cardinal Theodore McCarrick.
item.dc:creator: JASON HOROWITZ

item.title: In World’s ‘Happiest’ Countries, Signs of a Happiness Gap
item.media:description: Midsummer Festival in Leksand, Sweden. Most young citizens of the Nordic states have little to worry about in terms of education, health and jobs, but the pressure to do well and achieve are extraordinarily high.
item.media:credit: David B. Torch for The New York Times
item.description: In the five Nordic countries, an average of 12.3 percent of the population is “struggling” or “suffering,” according to new research.
item.dc:creator: MARTIN SELSOE SORENSEN

item.title: Australia’s New Prime Minister, Scott Morrison, Appoints a Cabinet
item.media:description: Scott Morrison, Australia’s new prime minister, said his “new generation team” would “begin the process of healing.”
item.description: After a week of political chaos, the most significant changes involved foreign affairs, immigration and energy.
item.dc:creator: DAMIEN CAVE

item.title: Police in Turkey Break Up Mothers’ Weekly Vigil
item.media:description: Emine Ocak, who is said to be in her 80s, was detained by the police in Istanbul on Saturday. She has attended vigils regularly since her son disappeared in 1995.
item.description: Officers used tear gas to stop a regular demonstration to remember people thought to have disappeared in police custody. Nearly 50 people were arrested.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Didi Suspends Carpooling Service in China After 2nd Passenger Is Killed
item.media:description: A driver using the Didi Chuxing app in Guilin, China. A string of crimes has raised questions about Didi’s ability to protect women who use its services.
item.description: The Chinese ride-hailing giant, which also fired two executives, has been criticized for not addressing the safety concerns of women who use its services.
item.dc:creator: SUI-LEE WEE

item.title: Live Briefing: Pope Francis in Ireland: Call for Resignation Further Clouds Visit
item.media:description: Archbishop Carlo Maria Viganò, a former apostolic nuncio to the United States, wrote a 7,000-word letter asserting that Pope Francis had known about the abuses of Cardinal Theodore McCarrick years before they became public.
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Charles Rex Arbogast
item.description: A former top Vatican official asserted that the pope had known of abuses by a disgraced U.S. prelate and called on Francis to resign.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Residents: 12. Average Age: 75. Biggest Challenge: Avoiding Extinction.
item.media:description: The Swiss village of Corippo, which has only 12 full-time residents.
item.media:credit: Maxime Fossat for The New York Times
item.description: In Corippo, Switzerland, the average age is 75, and the village has far more abandoned homes, 30, than residents, 12. But officials have a grand plan to fill those empty houses with tourists.
item.dc:creator: RAPHAEL MINDER

item.title: Copenhagen Dispatch: In Anarchic Corner of Copenhagen, Police and Dealers Play Cat and Mouse
item.media:description: The open-air drug market known as Pusher Street in Christiania Freetown, a neighborhood in Copenhagen.
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.description: Danish authorities tolerate Freetown Christiania, a long-running utopian experiment with an open-air drug market. But tolerance has its limits, and the mood in Denmark is tilting toward law-and-order.
item.dc:creator: ELLEN BARRY

item.title: Pope Francis Acknowledges Church Sex Abuse in Ireland
item.description: In the first speech during his visit to Ireland, the pope acknowledged “the abuse of young people by members of the church” and the church’s failure to “address these repugnant crimes,” but largely focused on other issues.
